message:
fix(security): upgrade Next.js and React to patch CVE-2025-66478

- Upgrade Next.js from 16.0.3 to 16.0.7
- Upgrade React from 19.2.0 to 19.2.1
- Upgrade React DOM from 19.2.0 to 19.2.1
- Update eslint-config-next to match Next.js version

Critical RCE vulnerability in React Server Components Flight protocol
with CVSS score 10.0. Patches deserialization flaw that allowed
unauthenticated remote code execution.
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
refactor(content): comprehensive quality improvements across educational materials

This commit implements extensive improvements to the AED III educational platform,
focusing on content quality, pedagogical structure, and student learning experience.

Major Changes:
- Remove 107 lines of duplicate content (100% elimination)
- Fix 230 orthographic errors (ligature corruption from PDF conversion)
- Correct broken code blocks in backtracking and AVL implementation files
- Complete rewrite of cryptography.md (2,312‚Üí526 lines, removed 773 images)
- Reduce mochila.md by 68% (420‚Üí134 lines) with improved pedagogy

Content Enhancements:
- Add prerequisites sections to 8 key files with study time estimates
- Reorganize CONTENT_MAPPING for logical pedagogical progression
- Expand exercises to 3-tier system (basic/intermediate/advanced) + integrative projects
- Add 40+ graded exercises across multiple topics

Automation Scripts (550 lines):
- detect-duplications.js: Section-based duplication detection
- detect-consecutive-duplications.js: Consecutive block analysis
- fix-orthography.js: Automated correction of 230 encoding errors

author: Claude

message:
feat: add interactive tree visualizer for AVL and Red-Black trees

Implemented a fully interactive tree visualization tool that allows students to:
- Insert and delete values in real-time
- Observe automatic balancing (AVL rotations)
- See height and balance factor for each node
- Generate random trees for experimentation
- Track operation history

Features:
üå≥ AVL Tree Visualizer
  - Automatic balancing with rotations (Left/Right/Left-Right/Right-Left)
  - Real-time balance factor calculation
  - Visual indicators for balanced/unbalanced nodes
  - Height tracking per node

üî¥‚ö´ Red-Black Tree Visualizer
  - Color-based balancing visualization (coming soon: colors)
  - Rotation and recoloring animations
  - Property validation

Integration:
- Embedded directly into markdown content using ```tree-avl and ```tree-rbt code blocks
- Added visualizers to AVL content (001_-_AVL.md)
- Added visualizers to Red-Black tree content (003_-_Arvore_Rubro_Negra.md)
- Seamless integration with existing markdown renderer

Educational Benefits:
- Interactive learning: students can experiment with different sequences
- Visual feedback: see balancing happen in real-time
- Suggested exercises: try sequences mentioned in the theory
- Better understanding of tree operations and complexity

Similar to: https://www.cs.usfca.edu/~galles/visualization/RedBlack.html

author: Claude

message:
fix(pdf): improve PDF.js worker configuration and error handling

Fixed PDF viewer errors when attempting to draw annotations by
improving worker configuration and adding comprehensive error handling.

Changes:
- Changed worker URL to use https:// protocol instead of //
- Added onDocumentLoadError callback for better error logging
- Added error state UI for failed PDF loads
- Improved canvas resize logic with try-catch and validation
- Added timeout delay before initial canvas resize
- Added error boundaries to prevent crashes

These changes prevent the "Cannot read properties of null" error
that occurred when the PDF.js worker failed to communicate properly,
and provide better user feedback when PDFs fail to load.

- Prevent page breaks inside code blocks, tables, and headings
- Display table headers on each printed page
- Show URLs for external links in print

- Add page break utility classes for manual control

Users can now print content pages cleanly without unnecessary UI
elements, with proper page breaks and professional formatting.

author: anderson-ufrj

message:
fix(pwa): resolve manifest 401 error with route handler

Fixes PWA manifest 401 authentication error on Vercel by converting static file to API route handler.

Problem:
- manifest.json in public/ directory returned 401 on Vercel
- Static file headers configuration didn't work
- PWA installation failed due to manifest fetch error

Solution:
- Created /app/manifest.json/route.ts as API route handler
- Moved manifest data from static JSON to TypeScript
- Set proper headers via NextResponse
- Removed static manifest.json from public directory
- Cleaned up unnecessary next.config headers

Technical implementation:
- GET route handler returning JSON with proper headers
- Content-Type: application/manifest+json
- Cache-Control for optimal performance
- Static route generation (‚óã symbol in build)

Impact:
- PWA manifest now loads successfully (200 OK)
- No more 401 errors in production
- App installable on all devices
- Better Vercel deployment compatibility
- Proper PWA metadata delivery
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
fix(vlibras): prevent widget from disappearing on navigation

Fixes VLibras widget persistence across page navigation and component re-renders.

Problem:
- VLibras appeared initially but disappeared after navigation
- Cleanup function was removing the script prematurely
- Widget wasn't persisting across Next.js client-side transitions

Solution:
- Removed cleanup function to prevent script removal
- Added check for existing VLibras script before loading
- Prevent duplicate widget initialization
- Allow VLibras to persist globally across navigation

Technical changes:
- Query for existing script before injection
- Conditional initialization based on script presence
- Removed useRef (no longer needed)
- No cleanup on unmount (intentional for persistence)
- Widget remains active throughout SPA navigation

Impact:
- VLibras now stays visible across all pages
- No flickering or disappearing during navigation
- Better user experience for deaf users
- Consistent accessibility feature availability

is opened, avoiding SSR compatibility issues with DOM APIs.

message:
fix(investigations): convert all datetime.now(UTC) to naive for PostgreSQL

PostgreSQL TIMESTAMP WITHOUT TIME ZONE columns reject timezone-aware
datetimes via asyncpg. This fix ensures all completed_at assignments
use naive datetimes by calling .replace(tzinfo=None).

Files updated:
- chat_zumbi_integration.py: 3 occurrences fixed
- investigation_service.py: 3 occurrences fixed
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
fix(investigations): convert timezone-aware datetime to naive for PostgreSQL

PostgreSQL TIMESTAMP WITHOUT TIME ZONE columns don't accept
timezone-aware datetimes via asyncpg. Convert to naive datetime
before saving to fix investigation status persistence.
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
feat(auth): implement proper API key validation

Add api_secret_key and api_keys_allowed to config.py for flexible
API authentication configuration.

Update AuthenticationMiddleware._validate_api_key to:
- Validate against configured api_secret_key
- Support multiple allowed API keys via api_keys_allowed
- Fall back to format-only validation if no keys configured
  (backwards compatibility for development)

The middleware is not active in production, so this change
is safe and doesn't affect the Vercel frontend.

Includes documentation for:
- Creating separate worker/beat services in Railway
- Troubleshooting Celery connection issues
- Cleaning up stuck investigations via API or script
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
feat(monitoring): implement real metrics tracking

Add actual tracking for monitoring metrics:
- failed_requests: track failed request count
- anomalies_detected: track total anomalies found
- detection_accuracy: calculate from true/false positives
- db_connections_active: get from SQLAlchemy pool
- db_query_time_ms: track query execution times
- cache_hit_rate: calculate from hits/misses

New tracking methods:
- track_request(success, duration)
- track_detection_result(is_true_positive)
- track_db_query_time(duration)
- track_cache_operation(is_hit)
- _get_db_connections_active()

Previously these metrics were hardcoded to 0.

feat(agents): add kids educational agents Monteiro Lobato and Tarsila

Implement two new RAG agents specialized for children's education:

- Monteiro Lobato (KidsProgrammingAgent): Teaches programming concepts
  using natural language and Sitio do Picapau Amarelo references
  (variables as "Emilia's boxes", loops as "Saci's jumps", etc.)

- Tarsila do Amaral (KidsDesignAgent): Teaches design, color theory,
  and aesthetics using her works (Abaporu) as references

Both agents feature:
- Extremely restrictive content filtering (50+ blocked topics)
- Safe educational topics only (100+ allowed)
- Automatic redirect for inappropriate questions
- Child-friendly language (ages 6-12)
- DSPy integration with Maritaca AI fallback
- Full test coverage (59 tests passing)

author: anderson-ufrj

message:
feat(chat): route specialized agents to knowledge base in streaming

The streaming endpoint was bypassing specialized agents' process method
and using DSPy directly, which doesn't have access to their knowledge.

Now when user explicitly requests bo_bardi or santos_dumont:
- Stream endpoint calls agent's process method with process_chat action
- Agent uses its _answer_question method with full knowledge base
- Falls back to DSPy only if agent processing fails

This ensures Bo Bardi knows about Next.js 15 and Santos-Dumont
knows about Railway deployment when users ask via streaming chat.
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
fix(agents): add process_chat action handler for chat integration

The main chat endpoint sends action="process_chat" but Bo Bardi and
Santos-Dumont only handled specific actions (guide, teach, etc.).

This caused the agents to return error responses, falling back to
generic Drummond LLM answers that don't use the specialized knowledge.

Now both agents:
- Handle process_chat action from chat endpoint
- Extract user message from payload
- Process using _answer_question with full knowledge base
- Return proper responses with their personality and expertise
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
fix(agents): add critical facts to personality prompts for LLM context

The chat endpoint uses LLM (Maritaca AI) with personality prompts, not the
static knowledge dictionaries. This caused incorrect responses about:
- Framework (saying "React" instead of "Next.js 15")
- Deployment (generic response instead of "Railway")

Bo Bardi prompt now includes:
- Full Next.js 15 stack with App Router
- Zustand for state management
- Tailwind, Supabase, Serwist, Vitest, Playwright
- Frontend repository link
- Explicit instruction to say "Next.js 15" not just "React"

Santos-Dumont prompt now includes:
- Railway deployment info (not HuggingFace)
- Maritaca AI as primary LLM (Groq deprecated)
- Anthropic Claude as backup
- Frontend reference with redirect to Bo Bardi

- Normalizes unicode and whitespace

message:
feat(routing): diversify agent selection for better expertise utilization

Change agent routing strategy from 99% Abaporu to distributed model:

Before (all to orchestrator):
- investigate -> abaporu
- fraud_detection -> oxossi
- All tasks centralized

After (specialized routing):
- investigate -> zumbi (specialist investigator)
- corruption_indicators -> obaluaie (corruption specialist)
- fraud_detection -> obaluaie
- analyze/statistical -> anita (statistical analyst)
- report -> tiradentes (reporter)
- text_analysis -> machado
- legal_compliance -> bonifacio
- security_audit -> maria_quiteria
- regional -> lampiao
- social_equity -> dandara
- data/search -> oxossi

Abaporu now reserved for complex multi-agent orchestration:
- orchestrate, complex_investigation, multi_source, status

Tests updated to verify:
- Agent distribution is balanced (< 50% Abaporu)
- At least 5 different agents used for common intents
- All 29 routing tests pass
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
feat(chat): improve intent classification and add instant responses

Expand intent detection patterns from 87% unknown to ~90% correct:
- Add 100+ new regex patterns for Brazilian Portuguese variations
- Support regional greetings (eai, salve, opa, fala)
- Add patterns for government entities, values, temporal queries
- Improve ABOUT_SYSTEM detection (creator, history, agents queries)

Add instant responses for simple intents (no LLM needed):
- GREETING responses now ~0ms vs ~7s (700x faster)
- HELP/HELP_REQUEST instant assistance
- ABOUT_SYSTEM instant project info
- THANKS and GOODBYE quick replies

Add short-circuit logic to /message and /stream endpoints:
- High confidence intents (>=0.7) return instant responses
- Preserves user choice when agent_id is specified
- Maintains chat history for all interactions

Add comprehensive test suite (156 tests, 91.6% pass rate):
- TestGreetingDetection: 25 regional variations
- TestInvestigateDetection: 23 contract/government queries
- TestAboutSystemDetection: 25 system/creator queries
- TestFraudDetection: 11 corruption/anomaly patterns
- TestEdgeCases: SQL injection, XSS, unicode handling

message:
feat(chat): integrate real-time contract search into streaming chat

When a user asks about contracts via chat streaming, the system now:
- Detects contract search intent using keywords and intent classification
- Uses ChatInvestigativeService to fetch REAL contracts from Portal da Transpar√™ncia
- Streams search progress and individual contracts in real-time
- Returns contracts with download_available flag for JSON/CSV/TXT export

This enables the frontend chat interface to naturally search and display
real government contracts during conversations with agents.

Keywords that trigger real contract search:
- contrato/contratos, buscar/pesquisar/listar contratos
- Ministry names: sa√∫de, educa√ß√£o, defesa, justi√ßa, etc.
- Organization mentions: minist√©rio, √≥rg√£o

message:
fix(transparency): resolve truncated URLs in coverage map endpoint

The coverage map was incorrectly extracting base URLs by splitting on '/api'
which caused URLs like 'https://api.portaldatransparencia.gov.br' to become
'https:/' because 'api' appears in the domain.

Solution: Use urllib.parse.urlparse to properly extract scheme and netloc.

Before (broken):
- https://api.portaldatransparencia.gov.br/api-de-dados ‚Üí https:/
- https://apidatalake.tesouro.gov.br/ords ‚Üí https:/
- https://api-publica.datajud.cnj.jus.br ‚Üí https:/

After (fixed):
- https://api.portaldatransparencia.gov.br/api-de-dados ‚Üí https://api.portaldatransparencia.gov.br
- https://apidatalake.tesouro.gov.br/ords ‚Üí https://apidatalake.tesouro.gov.br
- https://api-publica.datajud.cnj.jus.br ‚Üí https://api-publica.datajud.cnj.jus.br

Fixes broken links in the Transparency Map (/pt/app/mapa).

message:
feat(orchestration): add public servant salary query detection

Implement keyword-based detection for salary queries to fix
misclassification issue where queries like "Quanto ganha a professora
Aracele?" were incorrectly classified as general_query instead of
supplier_investigation.

Changes:
- Added SALARY_KEYWORDS list (12 keywords: sal√°rio, ganha, remunera√ß√£o, etc.)
- Added PUBLIC_SERVANT_KEYWORDS list (14 roles: professor, m√©dico, servidor, etc.)
- Added MIN_WORDS_FOR_NAME_QUERY constant (4 words minimum)
- Implemented dual detection patterns:
  * Primary: salary keyword + role keyword (90% confidence)
  * Secondary: salary keyword + person name (85% confidence)
- Added contract keyword exclusion to prevent false positives

Test Results:
- All salary queries now classify as supplier_investigation (90% conf)
- Contract queries still correctly classify as contract_anomaly_detection
- Zero false positives in 5 test variations

Impact:
- Fixes critical gap in intent classification
- Enables Portal da Transpar√™ncia SIAPE API integration
- Supports complete traceability for salary data queries

Technical Notes:
- Method has 7 return statements (one per pattern) - intentional design
- Each return represents distinct detection pattern with different confidence
- Keyword-based for fast classification without LLM dependency

Files Modified:
- src/services/orchestration/query_planner/intent_classifier.py (lines 74-250)

Related: User requirement for real government data fetching with traceability

message:
feat(traceability): implement complete data source traceability

Add comprehensive traceability metadata to all agent responses showing
exactly where data came from, which APIs were called, and execution details.
This is critical for a transparency system where users must verify sources.

Implementation:
- Enhanced AgentDataIntegration with traceability metadata
- Added data_sources, apis_called, stage_details tracking
- Included timing info, status, and error details per stage
- Created test suite with 4 realistic scenarios (100% pass rate)
- Comprehensive documentation of traceability format

Traceability Format Includes:
- data_sources: List of all government APIs consulted
- apis_called: APIs per execution stage
- stage_details: Complete breakdown (status, duration, errors)
- total_api_calls: Count of unique API calls
- timestamp: Exact investigation start time
- investigation_id: Unique identifier for audit trail

Test Results:
- 4/4 scenarios passed (Salary, Contracts, Demographics, Complex)
- Traceability metadata correctly populated
- Human-readable format for console output
- JSON format ready for frontend integration

Examples:
Query: "Quais contratos do munic√≠pio de Muzambinho?"
Traceability shows:
- APIs called: portal_transparencia, pncp
- Stage: contract_collection (3.21s, failed)
- Errors: Missing parameters, method not found
- Investigation ID: 9b898639-33e1-4bf0-85ea-1fda351b1292

Impact:
- Users can verify where every piece of data came from
- Complete audit trail for all investigations
- Debugging is much easier with detailed execution logs
- Foundation for compliance and accountability

Files:
- Modified: src/services/agent_data_integration.py (added traceability)
- Created: docs/architecture/TRACEABILITY_FORMAT.md (full spec)
- Created: scripts/test_realistic_scenarios.py (test suite)

docs(agents): add comprehensive modernization sprint changelog

detailed statistics, lessons learned, and recommendations for future work.

  * Overview of 9 agents modernized
  * Detailed statistics table with coverage, warnings, and datetime fixes
  * Critical bug fix documentation (Nan√£ timezone comparison)
  * Coverage discovery analysis (Maria Quit√©ria 87% ‚Üí 23.23% revealed)
  * Tier promotions (3 agents to Tier 1)
  * Warnings reduction breakdown (224 total)
  * Commit quality metrics
  * Lessons learned and next steps

Updated Files:
- docs/agents/01-README.md: Added sprint highlights section
  * Version bump: 2.3.0 ‚Üí 2.4.0
  * Last updated: 2025-11-18 ‚Üí 2025-11-21
  * New "Recent Updates" section linking to changelog
  * Key metrics: 9 agents, 90 datetime fixes, 224 warnings reduced
  * Promotion announcements for Tier 1 agents

Sprint Statistics:
- Agents modernized: 9 (Abaporu, Obaluai√™, Drummond, Oscar Niemeyer,
  Machado, Bonif√°cio, Maria Quit√©ria, Dandara, Nan√£)
- datetime.utcnow() eliminated: 90 (72 code + 18 tests)
- Warnings reduced: 224 total across all agents
- Bugs fixed: 1 critical (Nan√£ timezone comparison)
- Tier promotions: 3 agents to Tier 1 (Obaluai√™, Oscar Niemeyer, Machado)
- Documentation corrections: 6 agents with coverage mismatches
- Commits: 9 professional commits with detailed changelogs

Key Discoveries:
- Maria Quit√©ria has 23.23% actual vs 87% documented coverage (64pp gap)
- Nan√£ had critical timezone comparison bug causing runtime errors
- Machado achieved highest coverage: 94.19%
- Average documentation accuracy: 67% had errors >5 percentage points

Lessons Learned:
- Documentation accuracy is critical - 67% of agents had inaccurate coverage
- Automated coverage tracking needed in CI/CD
- Timezone-aware datetime prevents subtle runtime bugs
- Test coverage should be merge requirement

Next Steps:

- Apply modernization to remaining 7 agents
- Implement automated coverage badges in documentation
- Add timezone-aware test fixtures

Sprint Metrics:
- Duration: ~4 hours
- Productivity: 2.25 agents/hour
- Quality: 100% test pass rate maintained
- Files modified: 27 (18 agent, 9 test, 9 doc)
- Lines changed: ~500 total

This comprehensive documentation ensures the modernization work is fully
traceable and provides valuable insights for future maintenance and development.

message:
refactor(agents): modernize nana datetime to python 3.13 standard and fix timezone bug

Replace 11 deprecated datetime.utcnow() calls with datetime.now(UTC) for
timezone-aware operations. Fixes critical timezone comparison bug and reduces
deprecation warnings by 18.

Changes:
- src/agents/nana.py: Fixed 6 datetime.utcnow() calls
  * Line 304: timestamp in context enrichment
  * Line 322: memory_entry ID generation
  * Line 433: semantic memory ID generation
  * Line 641: cutoff_date calculation for memory forgetting
  * Line 652: timestamp fallback in memory retrieval
  * Line 915: consolidation_timestamp in metadata
- tests/unit/agents/test_nana.py: Fixed 5 datetime.utcnow() calls
  * Lines: 127, 170, 551, 586, 662
- All 32 tests passing (1 skipped), warnings reduced: 96 ‚Üí 78 (-18 warnings)

Critical Bug Fix:
- Fixed timezone-aware comparison bug in _forget_memories (lines 651-655)
- Issue: datetime.fromisoformat() returns naive datetime when ISO string lacks timezone
- Solution: Added timezone check and conversion to UTC if naive
- Error fixed: "can't compare offset-naive and offset-aware datetimes"
- Impact: Memory forgetting by age now works correctly

Documentation Corrections:
- Updated coverage from documented 80.97% to actual 80.16%
- Test count: 25 ‚Üí 32 tests passing (1 skipped)
- Missing coverage: 50 ‚Üí 55 statements
- Status: Tier 1 ‚Üí Tier 2 (80.16% is below 90% threshold)
- Updated last modified date to 2025-11-21

Technical Details:
- Import changed: from datetime import UTC, datetime, timedelta
- Pattern: datetime.utcnow() ‚Üí datetime.now(UTC)
- Timezone handling: Added .replace(tzinfo=UTC) for naive datetimes
- No other functional changes
- All tests passing (32/32, 1 skipped)
- Coverage: 80.16% (311/366 statements)

Missing Coverage Areas:
- Lines 241-263: Memory importance calculation
- Lines 382-383, 410-411: Error handling branches
- Lines 509-510, 581, 607-608: Auxiliary methods
- Lines 663-680: Importance-based forgetting strategy
- Lines 716-722, 734-736: Consolidation helpers
- Lines 772, 795: Pattern-based forgetting
- Lines 861-863: Additional consolidation logic
- Lines 961-965, 978-984, 992-1004: Utility methods

Note: Agent maintains strong Tier 2 status (80-89% coverage) with documentation
closely matching reality (-0.81 percentage points). This is one of the most
accurately documented agents in the system.

Replace 404 Not Found at API root with comprehensive welcome message
providing system information, available endpoints, and quick start guide.

Features:
- System status and version information
- Links to documentation (Swagger UI, ReDoc, OpenAPI JSON)
- List of main API endpoints (health, agents, chat, investigations)
- Feature highlights (16 agents, 30+ APIs, SSE streaming)
- Agent tier breakdown (Tier 1, 2, 3 with Brazilian identities)
- Quick start guide with example API calls
- Support links (GitHub, docs, issues)
- Production environment info (Railway, uptime stats)

Response Example:
{
  "message": "üáßüá∑ Welcome to Cidad√£o.AI API",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "status": "operational",
  "agents": {"available": 16, "tier_1": [...], ...},
  "quick_start": {...},
  ...
}

Impact:
- Better developer experience (clear entry point)
- No more confusing 404 at /api/v1/
- Self-documenting API structure
- Easier onboarding for new developers

Files:
- src/api/routes/root.py (new, 83 lines)
- src/api/app.py (import + router registration)
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
docs(planning): add realistic V1.0 delivery plan for November 2025

Create comprehensive delivery plan based on actual project status with
frontend already in production and chat working end-to-end.

Actual Status (Updated):
- Backend: 98% ready (Railway production stable, all tests passing)
- Frontend: 90% ready (Vercel deployed, connected to backend, chat working)
- Integration: 85% ready (end-to-end functional)

Remaining Work (10 days):
- Frontend polish: 4-5 days (UX, landing page, SEO, performance)
- Documentation: 2 days (README, user guide, video demo)
- User testing: 1 day (5-7 external testers)
- Marketing prep: 1 day (LinkedIn, Twitter, GitHub release)
- Backend minor fixes: 0.5 day (API root, logs validation)
- Buffer: 1 day (unexpected issues)

Delivery Strategy:
- Focus on polishing existing features, NOT adding new ones
- Documentation is critical (2 full days allocated)
- User testing on DAY 27 (early validation)
- Marketing prep on DAY 28 (communication ready)
- Launch on DAY 30 (November 30, 2025)

Key Principle: Ship functional MVP, NOT perfection
V1.1 improvements planned for December 2025

Files:
- PLANO_ENTREGA_REALISTA_NOV_2025.md (realistic updated plan)
- PLANO_ENTREGA_NOVEMBRO_2025.md (initial conservative plan)
author: anderson-ufrj

- test_chirp3_quality.py - Chirp3 voice quality validation
- test_all_google_voices.py - Complete Google TTS voice catalog

Purpose:
- API endpoint validation
- Performance baseline establishment
- WebSocket real-time communication testing
- GraphQL query optimization
- Load capacity measurement
- Voice interface quality assurance

message:
perf: optimize TTFB and caching for RES 95+ target

Phase 6-7 Performance Optimizations:

- Add RoutePrefetcher component for idle-time route preloading
- Implement ISR (1h revalidate) for static pages (/about, /agents, /manifesto)
- Convert agents pages from client to server components for better caching
- Add Supabase indexes for agora tables (user_id, created_at)
- Optimize Service Worker with CacheFirst/StaleWhileRevalidate strategies

Cache configuration:
- Static assets (JS/CSS): 30 days
- Images: 60 days
- Fonts: 1 year
- Agent avatars: 30 days
- HTML pages: NetworkFirst with 3s timeout

Expected improvements:
- ISR reduces TTFB on static pages
- SW caching eliminates repeat asset fetches
- DB indexes speed up Agora queries
- Route prefetching improves navigation UX

message:
fix(lint): resolve no-misused-promises warnings in event handlers

Wrap async functions with void operator when passed to event handlers
that expect void returns. This prevents unhandled promise rejections
and satisfies TypeScript strict promise checking.

Files fixed (24 total):
- Agora pages: atividades, chat, configuracoes, contract, diario,
  kids/chat, kids/dashboard, kids/page, leituras, login, onboarding,
  pais/dashboard, pais/page, perfil, ranking, selecao, trilhas,
  verificar
- App pages: atividades, chat, configuracoes, investigacoes/[id],
  investigacoes/nova, investigacoes/page

Pattern applied:
- onClick={asyncHandler} ‚Üí onClick={() => void asyncHandler()}
- onSubmit={asyncHandler} ‚Üí onSubmit={(e) => void asyncHandler(e)}
- callback={asyncHandler} ‚Üí callback={(arg) => void asyncHandler(arg)}

Update test expectation to reflect new behavior where Supabase

author: anderson-ufrj

message:
perf: lazy load Sentry and optimize images

- Lazy load Sentry using dynamic import after page interactive
- Use requestIdleCallback with 5s timeout for optimal timing
- Remove unoptimized flag from background images
- Add quality=60 for optimized image compression

Bundle impact:
- First Load JS: 262 kB ‚Üí 173 kB (-34%)
- Sentry (~91 kB) now loads on-demand after hydration
- Background images now use Next.js optimization
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
perf(middleware): skip Supabase auth check for public routes

- Move route type checks BEFORE Supabase client creation
- Only call getUser() for protected and auth routes
- Skip Supabase network call entirely for public pages
- Should reduce TTFB from ~2.5s to ~500ms on public pages

Routes optimized (no Supabase call):
- /pt, /en (landing pages)
- /pt/about, /pt/agents, /pt/manifesto (content pages)
- All other public routes

Routes with auth check (unchanged):
- /pt/app/*, /pt/agora/* (protected)
- /pt/login, /pt/agora/login (auth routes)
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
perf(bundle): lazy load PostHog analytics library

Use dynamic import to load PostHog (156KB) only when needed,
removing it from the initial page load bundle.

Changes:
- Convert posthog-config.ts to use async dynamic import
- PostHog library loads 2 seconds after page render
- Added isInitializing guard to prevent race conditions
- Maintains full analytics functionality

Bundle impact:
- PostHog no longer in First Load JS
- Library loads on-demand after critical rendering
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
perf(bundle): remove Sentry replayIntegration from initial load

Remove replayIntegration to significantly reduce client bundle size.
Session replay can be enabled separately if needed.

Results:
- First Load JS: 340 KB ‚Üí 262 KB (-23%)
- Sentry bundle: 169 KB ‚Üí 91 KB (-46%)
- Sentry internal: 89.4 KB ‚Üí 11.1 KB (-88%)

The replay integration was adding ~78KB to every page load.
Error tracking and performance monitoring remain fully functional.
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
perf(bundle): fix lucide-react tree-shaking with static imports

Replace require('lucide-react') with static ES module imports
to enable proper tree-shaking by webpack/Next.js bundler.

Results:
- lucide-react chunk: 597 KB ‚Üí 39 KB (-93%)
- /pt/app/chat: 865 KB ‚Üí 727 KB (-16%)
- /pt/agora: 922 KB ‚Üí 784 KB (-15%)

The require() calls were preventing tree-shaking, causing
the entire lucide-react library to be bundled instead of
only the ~110 icons actually used.
author: anderson-ufrj

author: anderson-ufrj

message:
fix(test): improve test isolation with singleFork: false

Change vitest pool config from singleFork: true to singleFork: false
to ensure each test file runs in its own isolated process. This
prevents window object contamination between test files.

Add safety check in vitest.setup.ts to catch window being undefined.

Tradeoff: test duration increases from ~1s to ~5s but all tests pass.
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
fix(test): use global localStorage mock, remove vi.unstubAllGlobals

Replace local localStorage stubs with global mock from vitest.setup.ts.
Remove vi.unstubAllGlobals() calls that were removing global mocks
needed by subsequent test files.

message:
refactor(agora): implement unified auth architecture

Sprint 3 complete - Agora state management refactoring:

- Create unified AgoraUser type (types/agora.ts)
  - Single source of truth for all user fields
  - Consolidates 3 separate definitions

- Create user converter utilities (lib/agora/user-converter.ts)
  - Single convertToAgoraUser() function
  - Eliminates 300 lines of duplicate conversion code

- Create Agora reducer (hooks/agora/agora-reducer.ts)
  - Centralized state management with typed actions
  - Action creators and selectors included

- Update UnifiedAuthProvider (hooks/use-unified-auth.tsx)
  - Uses unified AgoraUser type
  - Single logout implementation via navigationSessionService
  - Integrates profile loading

- Migrate layout to use UnifiedAuthProvider
  - Replaces AgoraAuthProvider in app/pt/agora/layout.tsx
  - Maintains backward compatibility

- Update ADR-002 with implementation details
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
test(services): update investigation.service tests for Result<T> pattern

- Update all tests to use isSuccess/isFailure type guards
- Add tests for new error codes (NOT_FOUND, DB_QUERY_ERROR)
- Verify failure results contain correct error codes
- Add mock for logger to prevent console noise
- Fix 19 failing tests (22 tests passing)

Part of Sprint 4: Test coverage improvements
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
docs(adr): add ADR-002 for Agora state management architecture

Document current provider structure and defer refactoring:
- Analyze AgoraAuthProvider + AgoraProvider architecture
- Document risks of complete refactoring (1900+ lines)
- Propose incremental improvement strategy
- Define monitoring criteria for future reevaluation

Decision: Defer major refactoring, focus on tests first.

Part of Sprint 3: Architecture documentation

message:
perf(home): remove artificial 500ms delay and add memoization

author: anderson-ufrj

message:
refactor(auth): use non-blocking logout with sendBeacon

Replace async logout with sync approach using sendBeacon.
This prevents UI from hanging on logout in the main App area.

Changes:
- logout function now sync, sends beacon then redirects immediately
- Supabase signOut is fire-and-forget (no await)
- Update type signature from Promise<void> to void
- Telemetry cleanup happens reliably via sendBeacon API
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
refactor(kids): use non-blocking exit with sendBeacon

Replace async disableKidsMode with sync approach using sendBeacon.
This prevents UI from hanging when exiting Kids mode.

Changes:
- handleExitKidsMode now sync, sends beacon then redirects immediately
- Telemetry cleanup happens reliably via sendBeacon API
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
fix(telemetry): ensure cleanup on tab close and page navigation

Add multiple event listeners for reliable telemetry cleanup:
- beforeunload: page refresh/close
- visibilitychange: tab close (more reliable on mobile)
- pagehide: navigation away from page

Now sends cleanup beacons on visibilitychange='hidden' immediately,
ensuring telemetry is stopped even when user closes tab without
clicking "Sair".
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
refactor(agora): use non-blocking logout with sendBeacon

Replace async logout/session cleanup with synchronous beacon-based approach.
This prevents the UI from hanging on "Saindo..." state.

Changes:
- handleLogoutConfirm now sync, sends beacon then redirects immediately
- handleSwitchMode simplified to beacon + redirect
- Remove unused endSession and currentSession from useAgora destructure
- Telemetry cleanup happens reliably via sendBeacon
author: anderson-ufrj

message:
refactor(agora): simplify logout modal to avoid async hanging

Remove async loading state that caused "Saindo..." to hang forever.
Now the modal just confirms intent - actual cleanup happens via beacon.

Changes:
- Remove isLoading state and spinner
- Change onConfirm from async to sync
- Remove hasActiveSession and sessionDuration props
- Simplify to just open/close/confirm flow
author: anderson-ufrj

This is a 57% reduction in page complexity while
maintaining identical functionality and UX.

message:
feat(chat): add useChatPage composite hook

Create new composite hook that consolidates all chat page logic:
- 15 useState hooks consolidated into single hook
- 4 useRef hooks for DOM references
- 8 useCallback handlers for user interactions
- 4 useEffect hooks for side effects

This hook reduces the chat page from 17 scattered hooks to
a single, well-organized interface that's easier to maintain
and test independently.

Exports: useChatPage, UseChatPageReturn interface

message:
docs(architecture): optimize Mermaid diagram visualization

**Problem**: Large complex Mermaid diagram (243 lines) was too big to visualize properly in browser

**Solution - Split into 3 focused diagrams**:
1. **Simplified high-level architecture** (40 lines)
   - Shows main layers: User, Frontend, Backend, Multi-Agent, Data, External APIs
   - Easier to understand overall system structure

2. **Sequence diagram for data flow** (19 lines)
   - End-to-end request/response flow
   - Shows interaction between components

3. **Detailed agent diagram** (expandable)
   - All 17 agents organized by category
   - Hidden in <details> tag to avoid cluttering
   - Users can expand when needed

**Benefits**:
- ‚úÖ Better mobile/tablet viewing
- ‚úÖ Faster rendering
- ‚úÖ Progressive disclosure (simple ‚Üí detailed)
- ‚úÖ Maintains all information from original diagram

message:
Fix ContextWindowExceededError after 3 retries in react loop (#9110)

* Initial plan

* Fix ContextWindowExceededError after 3 retries in react loop

When _call_with_potential_trajectory_truncation exhausts all retry
attempts, it now raises a clear ValueError instead of returning None.
This prevents the AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute
'next_thought' that occurred when accessing properties on the None
return value.

The ValueError is caught in forward/aforward and causes the loop to
break gracefully, allowing the extract phase to proceed with whatever
trajectory was collected.

Added tests for both sync and async versions of this scenario.

Co-authored-by: TomeHirata <33407409+TomeHirata@users.noreply.github.com>

* Address code review feedback: Fix comments and error messages

Co-authored-by: TomeHirata <33407409+TomeHirata@users.noreply.github.com>

* Remove unnecessary try-catch around truncate_trajectory

Co-authored-by: TomeHirata <33407409+TomeHirata@users.noreply.github.com>

* Remove docstrings from test functions

Co-authored-by: TomeHirata <33407409+TomeHirata@users.noreply.github.com>

* Combine sync and async context window tests into one test

Co-authored-by: TomeHirata <33407409+TomeHirata@users.noreply.github.com>

* Verify inputs passed to extract in test

Co-authored-by: TomeHirata <33407409+TomeHirata@users.noreply.github.com>

---------

message:
feat(gepa): add tool description optimization for multi-agent systems (#8928)

* feat(gepa): add tool description optimization for multi-agent systems

- Add optimize_tool_descriptions parameter (default False) to GEPA
- Extract tool descriptions from all nested modules via named_sub_modules()
- Apply optimized descriptions in DspyAdapter.build_program()
- Enables holistic optimization of tools across main and subagent modules
- Tests: 4 new tests, all 16 pass (4 new + 12 existing)

* style: fix ruff formatting (trailing whitespace)

* style: apply ruff formatting fixes

* feat(gepa): implement tool-specific proposer for tool descriptions

- Add ToolProposer with GenerateImprovedToolDescription signature
- Implement routing logic to separate tools from signatures
- Tools use ToolProposer, signatures use custom or parent default
- Backward compatible: preserves existing custom_instruction_proposer behavior
- Add test verifying routing splits components correctly

* docs(gepa): clean up multi-agent example code

- Define tool functions outside class for clarity
- Match structure of simple ReAct example
- Add clear comments explaining architecture
- Make code more readable and maintainable

* refactor(gepa): simplify tool reflective dataset with ReAct context reuse

Tools now copy ReAct's reflective data with tool-specific annotation
instead of complex trajectory extraction. This 15-line approach reuses
ReAct's existing context (thoughts, tool calls, observations) and adds
focused annotation for each tool.

Implementation:
- Tools receive full ReAct reflective examples (same trajectory context)
- Feedback prefixed: [Optimizing tool: 'X'] for focused optimization
- Reflection LM sees complete multi-step execution traces per tool

Benefits:
- Simpler: 15 lines vs 70+ line extraction approach
- Reuses code: No duplicate trajectory formatting logic
- Same context: Tools see full ReAct execution traces
- Clean: Removed all debug output

Tests:
- 4 focused tests following GEPA patterns (removed 1 redundant)
- 226KB fixture with 34 LM + 6 reflection calls
- All tests passing with gpt-5-nano traces

Documentation:
- Updated GEPA_Advanced.md with implementation details
- Explains reflective dataset construction approach

* fix(gepa): unify custom proposer routing for tools

* docs(gepa): clarify tool reflection prompt

* test: streamline GEPA tool optimization tests

* fix(gepa): streamline tool proposer formatting

* test(gepa): drop legacy dummy tool fixture

* docs(gepa): add tool-specific reflection prompt and metric example

- Add GenerateImprovedToolDescriptionFromFeedback signature documentation
- Include tool-aware metric example showing trajectory access
- Document tool prefix annotation in feedback
- Note component_selector applies to both signatures and tools
- Fix 'fundamentally' language per reviewer feedback

* docs(gepa): fix implementation details with accurate code flow

- Separate Pass 1 (predictor examples) and Pass 2 (tool aggregation)
- Clarify Generated Outputs includes full trajectory for ReAct
- Fix feedback annotation format to [Tool 'name' from 'predictor_key']
- Add Component Identification & Proposer Routing section
- Explain dual-proposer independence (custom proposer doesn't affect tool proposer)
- Use consistent terminology: 'predictor' and 'signature instructions'

* docs(gepa): remove backward compatibility note

Per reviewer feedback, backward compatibility should be implicit

* docs(gepa): improve usage examples with optimization visualization

- Add component_selector='all' to optimize all components together
- Show how to view optimized tool descriptions
- Add example output demonstrating improvement from vague to specific descriptions
- Remove unnecessary comments for cleaner examples

* docs(gepa): add design rationale comments for tool context sharing

- Document why full ReAct trajectory is shared with all tools
- Explain rationale: tool interdependencies, selection patterns, workflow context
- Add concrete example of optimization benefit
- Describe alternative considered (tool-specific filtering) and rejection reasoning
- Add future work section on joint tool optimization
- Present two architectural approaches: separate proposer vs extending ReAct proposer
- Include implementation details, benefits, challenges, and decision rationale

* docs(gepa): add tool optimization links to overview and parameter docs

- Add Tool Description Optimization section to GEPA overview.md with link to advanced guide
- Add documentation link to optimize_tool_descriptions parameter in gepa.py
- Addresses reviewer feedback to make tool optimization more discoverable

* docs(gepa): refine tool optimization scenarios and remove implementation details

- Restructure 'When to Use' as numbered list (1-5) per reviewer feedback
- Move section after implementation details for better flow
- Remove tool: prefix implementation detail from component identification
- Explain tool discovery via ReAct modules in user-friendly terms
- Add custom proposer compatibility clarification
- Address optional PR feedback items (11 & 13)

* docs(gepa): clarify future work section in code comments

- Add note that proposed architecture details may change
- Expand challenges with counterpoints and questions
- Mark implementation notes as optional to avoid overengineering

* refactor(gepa): unify ReAct optimization as single module

Treat ReAct as ONE unified module containing react predictor, extract
predictor, and tools as subcomponents - respecting both GEPA's module-level
optimization abstraction and DSPy's ReAct module design.

Before:
- Tools optimized separately from react/extract (multiple components)
- Each component had separate reflective dataset (3x redundant trajectories)
- Violated DSPy's ReAct abstraction (tools are subcomponents, not peers)

After:
- ReAct module optimized as single "react_module" component
- Joint optimization of react instruction + extract instruction + tool descriptions
- One reflective dataset per ReAct execution (no redundant trajectories)
- Respects GEPA's dict[str, str] contract (JSON config as string value)

Architecture:
- ReActModuleProposer: Handles entire ReAct module optimization
- Dynamic signature generation: Creates output fields for each tool/parameter
- Optional fields: Extract, tool descriptions, tool args (only improve what needs fixing)
- JSON config: {"react": "...", "extract": "...", "tools": {...}}

Benefits:
- Eliminates duplicate trajectories (addresses gepa#97)
- Coherent improvements (LM sees how components work together)
- Respects both GEPA and DSPy abstractions
- Enables cold-start optimization (tool args always available based on schema)

* test(gepa): add end-to-end ReAct module optimization test

Adds comprehensive test proving GEPA can optimize ReAct modules end-to-end:
- Baseline with minimal tool descriptions achieves 0% accuracy
- After optimization, achieves 100% accuracy
- Tests unified ReAct architecture (react + extract + tools as one module)

Key features:
- Uses stable SHA256 hashing for deterministic fixture replay
- Avoids Python's PYTHONHASHSEED randomization issues
- 189KB fixture with security check passed (no API keys/tokens)
- Verifies all components are optimized (react, extract, tool descriptions)

* fix(gepa): enable arg description optimization for ReAct tools

* chore: remove legacy test_gepa_tool_optimization.py

This test file was for the old architecture where tools were optimized
separately from ReAct modules. With the unified ReAct optimization approach,
this test is replaced by test_gepa_react_optimization.py which tests the
new architecture where ReAct modules (react + extract + tools) are optimized
as a single unified component.

* fix: restore accidentally removed score mismatch warning

* test: update fixture after arg description optimization fix

Regenerates fixture to match commit 3418b59e which changed how
tool arg descriptions are optimized. Reduces LM calls from 26‚Üí22
by improving the optimization process efficiency.

* fix(test): use JSON-based hashing for cross-version fixture stability

- Replace repr()-based hashing with json.dumps(sort_keys=True)
- Fixes CI failures caused by Python version differences (3.12.9 vs 3.12.11)
- repr() formatting can differ between Python micro versions
- JSON spec is standardized and stable across all versions
- Regenerate fixture with new hashing approach

* refactor(gepa): rename optimize_tool_descriptions to optimize_react_components

- Rename parameter to better reflect that we optimize all ReAct components
- Components include: react instructions, extract instructions, tool descriptions, and tool argument descriptions
- Update all code references, tests, and documentation
- No functional changes, pure rename for clarity

* docs(gepa): improve 'What is optimize_react_components?' section

- Clarify that specialized optimization applies only to dspy.ReAct modules
- Explain ReAct module structure (react predictor, extract predictor, tools)
- List all 4 optimizable components with clear descriptions
- Specify react instruction always optimized, others optional based on failures
- Simplify language: 'contradict' vs 'work together' instead of complex terms
- Add link to ReAct documentation for deeper dive

* docs(gepa): replace outdated tool-specific prompt with actual ReAct optimization prompt

- Rename section: 'Tool-Specific Reflection Prompt' ‚Üí 'ReAct Optimization Prompt'
- Replace GenerateImprovedToolDescriptionFromFeedback (doesn't exist) with GenerateImprovedReActDescriptionsFromFeedback (actual implementation)
- Show that prompt receives ALL components (react, extract, tools) and optimizes jointly
- Update metric example: tool_feedback_metric ‚Üí react_metric for clarity
- Remove outdated notes about tool-specific prefixes and component_selector behavior
- Clarify that tool descriptions/args are added dynamically via signature.append()

* docs(gepa): simplify 'How It Works' section with accurate routing behavior

* docs(gepa): remove outdated Implementation Details section

* docs(gepa): replace theoretical scenarios with real user pain points

* docs(gepa): fix usage examples reference to match updated scenarios

* docs(gepa): update inspect section to show all 4 ReAct components with correct syntax

* docs(gepa): rewrite Section 8 with accurate custom proposer behavior for ReAct

- Clarify custom proposer receives ALL components (regular + ReAct)
- Add realistic signature with ReAct failure patterns and component types
- Use exact naming from implementation: examples_with_feedback, component_reflective_data, propose_instruction
- Show _format_examples() helper matching real markdown formatting
- Remove regular component handling to keep example focused on ReAct
- Test code example validates successfully
- Fix contradiction: optimize_react_components must be True (not irrelevant)

docs(gepa): clarify custom proposer behavior in routing section

Change 'overrides the default routing' to 'receives all components and handles the optimization logic' to avoid confusion with optimize_react_components which still controls discovery/serialization

docs(gepa): remove discouraging recommendation from custom proposer section

Users reading this section want to learn how to implement custom proposers for ReAct - don't discourage them from doing so

* fix(gepa): fix top-level ReAct module lookup and remove tool name sanitization

- Fix ReAct module lookup to handle top-level modules correctly
  Previously failed to match 'self' path for top-level ReAct instances

- Remove tool name sanitization entirely
  Tool names are now used as-is in dynamic signatures
  Removed _sanitize_name() function and all calls to it
  Simplifies code and avoids surprising behavior

- Skip failing test_gepa_react_optimization
  Hash-based fixtures are fragile across Python versions

- Add debug logging to trace processing for troubleshooting

* refactor(gepa): unify ReAct module key handling and use constant

- Replace all magic string 'react_module' with REACT_MODULE_PREFIX constant
- Unify path normalization pattern across gepa.py and gepa_utils.py
- Rename 'prefix' to 'normalized_path' for clarity
- Simplify module lookup by using consistent normalization
- Remove awkward OR clause in ReAct module matching logic

This makes the codebase more maintainable with a single source of truth
for the module prefix and consistent naming throughout.

* test(gepa): add ReAct module detection tests for nested structures

- Add 3 comprehensive detection tests: single ReAct, mixed workflow (2 ReAct + ChainOfThought), orchestrator with 2 workers
- Tests validate full path preservation (bug fix validation)
- Uses monkey patching to capture base_program from gepa.optimize
- Helper functions for DRY: setup spy, create optimizer, assert detection
- Validates all ReAct components: react, extract, tools, tool metadata

* test(gepa): add comprehensive ReAct detection and reconstruction tests

Detection tests (3):
- test_single_react_module_detection: top-level ReAct module
- test_multi_react_workflow_detection: mixed ReAct + ChainOfThought (bug fix validation)
- test_nested_react_orchestrator_worker_detection: orchestrator with 2 workers as tools

Reconstruction tests (3):
- test_build_program_single_react: single ReAct module
- test_build_program_multi_react_workflow: mixed workflow with ReAct + non-ReAct
- test_build_program_orchestrator_with_workers: complex nested structure

Helper functions (12):
- setup_spy_for_base_program: captures base_program from gepa.optimize
- simple_metric_for_detection/reconstruction: test metrics
- create_gepa_optimizer_for_detection: creates optimizer
- assert_react_module_detected/updated: validates ReAct modules
- assert_regular_module_detected/updated: validates non-ReAct modules
- mock_optimized_react_module: mocks optimized candidate
- create_*_program: 3 reusable program builders

Validates:
- Full path preservation (bug fix)
- All 4 ReAct components (react, extract, tools, arg_desc)
- Non-ReAct module handling
- Deepcopy verification (original unchanged)
- Both detection and reconstruction phases

* test(gepa): add reflective dataset tests for multi-agent trajectory validation

Adds 2 new tests validating make_reflective_dataset captures complete trajectories:
- test_make_reflective_dataset_single_react: Single ReAct module
- test_make_reflective_dataset_orchestrator_with_workers: Multi-agent system (3 modules)

New helpers:
- simple_feedback: Reusable feedback function (consolidates 5 duplicates)
- assert_reflective_example_has_trajectory: Validates trajectory completeness

Tests validate:
- Complete trajectory capture (all iterations with thoughts/tools/observations)
- No duplicate/missing iterations
- Full path preservation in multi-agent systems
- Each module's trajectory captured separately

Improvements:
- Clean up docstrings and remove redundant comments
- Fix whitespace linter warnings (9 auto-fixed)
- Reduce from 1054 to 975 lines

All 8 tests passing (6 detection/reconstruction + 2 new reflective dataset)

* test(gepa): verify tool arg descriptions propagate to args schema

- Update assert_react_module_updated to check tool.args['param']['description']
- Add arg_desc to test cases for comprehensive validation
- Expose bug: GEPA updates arg_desc but not tool.args (what renders in prompts)

* fix(gepa): propagate arg_desc updates to tool.args for prompt rendering

tool.arg_desc is only used during Tool.__init__; updating it after creation
has no effect on prompts. Only tool.args is rendered, so GEPA must update
args for optimized descriptions to appear in prompts.

Fixes the bug where reflection LM improves tool parameter descriptions but
they don't show in actual prompts because arg_desc changes weren't propagated
to the args schema.

* test(gepa): remove fixture-based test and unused dependencies

* test(gepa): remove unused fixture file

* style: fix ruff linting issues (import formatting, whitespace, bare except)

* refactor(test): rename setup_spy_for_base_program to setup_capture_for_base_program for clarity

* docs(gepa): clarify why Tool.func uses placeholder lambda in proposer

* refactor(gepa): make all ReAct components optional with None default for selective optimization

* docs(gepa): clarify 'LM' as 'reflection LM' in comments for precision

* refactor(gepa): refine reflection prompt to guide concise, focused ReAct component optimization

Update the ReAct proposer's reflection signature to guide the LM toward more
appropriate output granularity and selective optimization.

Changes:
- Add context that components are progressively optimized across iterations
- Change 'and' to 'and/or' for abstraction/specificity (allows flexibility)
- Refine field descriptions to guide output style:
  * 'ReAct instruction for reasoning and tool selection' (functional context)
  * 'Extract instruction for answer extraction' (functional context)
  * 'Purpose of tool' (focuses on high-level what/why, not verbose how)
  * 'Usage of parameter' (focuses on specific usage, not essay)

The goal is to prevent overly verbose LM outputs (multi-paragraph tool/param
descriptions) while preserving exploration capability. Field descriptions now
provide functional context ('for reasoning', 'purpose', 'usage') that naturally
guides appropriate scope without being prescriptive about format or length.

This allows the reflection LM to determine the right level of detail based on
what's needed to fix failures, aligned with GEPA's general meta-prompt philosophy.

* docs(gepa): revise ReAct metric example to be general and extensible

Replace prescriptive 'minimize tool calls' example with educational progression
that shows users how to write effective metrics without forcing specific objectives.

Changes:
- Show simple metric first (just correctness feedback)
- Then show trajectory-based metric (accessing agent execution)
- Use clear for-loop instead of list comprehension for readability
- Follow DSPy docs conventions: answer_match variable, example/pred naming
- Remove 'minimize tool calls' directive - let users decide their objectives
- Add bullet points explaining what trajectory can reveal (tool selection,
  reasoning quality, efficiency) without prescribing how to use it
- Rename section to 'Writing Metrics for ReAct Optimization' (more actionable)

This aligns with GEPA's philosophy: provide general, extensible patterns that
users can adapt to their specific needs. Detailed examples can be shown in
tutorials rather than API documentation.

Addresses PR review comment 5 about prescriptive objectives in documentation.

* docs(gepa): replace custom proposer example with reference to ReActModuleProposer

Address PR review comment 6 by simplifying the custom proposer documentation.

Changes:
- Replace long inline implementation example with clickable GitHub link
- Point to ReActModuleProposer as reference implementation
- Add bulleted list of what the reference shows (parsing, dynamic signatures, etc.)
- Keep essential JSON structure and interface documentation
- Remove 100+ lines of redundant code example

Benefits:
- Less overwhelming for users (no duplicate code)
- Single source of truth (reference implementation)
- Clickable link to actual working code on GitHub
- Users can copy/modify real implementation instead of example

Addresses PR comment from @LakshyAAAgrawal about using reference instead
of full implementation example.

* docs(gepa): make custom proposer section more approachable and clear

Improve the custom proposer documentation to be more user-friendly while
maintaining technical accuracy.

Changes:
- Warmer, more inviting opening ("best way to start")
- Concrete example with 'search' tool instead of generic placeholders
- Plain English explanations for each component ("How the agent reasons...")
- Clear separation: "What you can improve" vs "What to preserve"
- Simpler code example with inline comments explaining ReAct vs regular
- Concise "reference shows how to" bullets (3 key points)
- More approachable tone without sacrificing precision

This makes the advanced feature more accessible to users who need custom
optimization logic beyond the defaults.

Follows up on the previous commit addressing PR comment about custom proposer example.

* docs(gepa): update ReAct reflection prompt to match current implementation

Sync documentation with actual reflection prompt after bd4cdac4:
- Add 'These components are progressively optimized' context
- Change to 'and/or specificity' for flexibility
- Update output field types to 'str | None' with default=None
- Refine field descriptions ('for reasoning and tool selection', 'for answer extraction')
- Add note about dynamic field descriptions ('Purpose of tool', 'Usage of parameter')

This ensures docs accurately reflect the current prompt design that guides
appropriate granularity without being prescriptive.

* feat(gepa): warn when ReAct modules detected but optimization disabled

Add warning message when GEPA detects ReAct modules in the program but
optimize_react_components=False. This helps users discover the ReAct
optimization feature.

Changes:
- Always traverse modules to detect ReAct instances
- If optimize_react_components=False, warn for each ReAct module found
- Shows module path to help users identify what would be optimized
- No behavioral changes when optimize_react_components=True

Addresses maintainer feedback to make the feature more discoverable.

* test(gepa): fix DummyLM configuration and remove exception swallowing

- Configure DummyLM with proper ReAct response format (next_thought, next_tool_name, next_tool_args)
- Remove try/except blocks that silently swallowed exceptions
- Add explanatory comments for why compile should now succeed
- Increase DummyLM repetitions (10‚Üí20) to support GEPA iterations

Addresses review feedback from @LakshyAAAgrawal requesting removal of
unexplained exception handling that masked real bugs.

All 8 tests now pass deterministically without silent failures.

* test(gepa): add failing tests for generic tool optimization

- Add 4 core tests for tool optimization beyond ReAct
- test_detect_single_tool: single Tool input field
- test_detect_tool_list: multiple tools with ordering
- test_skip_predictor_without_tools: negative case (passing)
- test_update_tool_and_predictor: reconstruction path

Tests use class-based signatures (required for type detection).
Currently failing (TDD approach) - implementation next.

* refactor(gepa): rename optimize_react_components to enable_tool_optimization

Rename flag to reflect generalization beyond ReAct modules:
- optimize_react_components ‚Üí enable_tool_optimization
- Update documentation to mention custom predictors using dspy.Tool
- Update warning message to use new flag name

This prepares for upcoming feature: generic tool optimization for any
predictor using dspy.Tool, not just dspy.ReAct modules.

* refactor(gepa): extract nested function to private method

Move build_propose_new_texts() from nested function in __init__ to
_build_propose_new_texts() private method per maintainer feedback.

Also simplify LM context handling by using unified context manager
pattern instead of if/else branching (18 lines ‚Üí 6 lines).

Changes:
- Extract _build_propose_new_texts() as private class method
- Simplify LM context: use 'with dspy.context(lm=self.reflection_lm or dspy.settings.lm)'
- Clean up __init__ (110+ lines nested function ‚Üí 1 line method call)

Benefits:
- Cleaner class structure (easier to scan __init__)
- Methods testable in isolation
- Reduced code duplication (-26 lines net)
- Addresses maintainer feedback: 'move helper function out as private method'

* feat(gepa): detect tool-using predictors via type checking

- Add type-based detection for predictors using dspy.Tool
- Initialize tool-using predictors with JSON structure
- Add inline helper function is_tool_field() for recursive type checking
- Handle Union/Optional types containing Tool
- Enable generic tool optimization beyond dspy.ReAct

* test(gepa): update ReAct tests for predictor-name-based keys

- Move inline imports to top of file
- Rename module_path ‚Üí predictor_name for clarity
- Update all assertions to use full predictor names (e.g., extract.predict)
- Update feedback_map keys to match predictor names
- Simplify multi-agent test assertions (20+ lines ‚Üí 10 lines)

All 8 ReAct optimization tests now passing with new key structure.

* test(gepa): use explicit predictor keys in tool optimization tests

- Replace unpacking pattern with explicit predictor names
- Remove duplicate inline imports (already at top)
- Use TOOL_MODULE_PREFIX:pred consistently across tests
- Improve test docstrings for clarity

All 3 tool tests still passing (1 skipped intentionally).

* feat(gepa): extract tools from runtime traces

Runtime tool discovery:
- Import Tool type for isinstance() checks
- Initialize tools_by_predictor dict to collect unique tools
- Add extract_tools_from_value() recursive helper function
- Extract tools from predictor trace inputs during iteration
- Handle single Tool, list[Tool], dict[str, Tool] structures
- Serialize tools to candidate JSON after all traces processed

Implements runtime tool discovery (Change 2).
Captures dynamically injected tools from actual usage patterns.

* feat(gepa): detect tool-using predictors at compile time

- Import TOOL_MODULE_PREFIX constant
- Detect predictors with dspy.Tool input fields
- Create prefixed keys: tool_module:{predictor_name}
- Use actual predictor name as JSON config key

Pairs with tool extraction (fe19dac5). Together they implement
compile-time detection + runtime extraction for generic tool modules.

* refactor(gepa): use predictor identity for ReAct detection

- Find extract/react predictors by object identity (not paths)
- Use actual predictor names as JSON config keys
- Module key uses extract_predictor_name for consistency
- Clearer comments about dynamic predictor names

More robust than path-based matching. Config keys are now actual
predictor names (e.g., "multi_agent.react", "multi_agent.extract.predict")
instead of generic "react"/"extract".

* test(gepa): refactor ReAct tests to use dynamic predictor names

- Add get_predictor_name() helper using object identity
- Remove all hardcoded predictor name strings
- Update mock_optimized_react_module() to accept react_module parameter
- Use expected_* naming convention for clarity
- All 11 tests passing with fully dynamic approach

* refactor(gepa): generalize proposer to support both ReAct and tool modules

- Rename ReActModuleProposer ‚Üí ToolModuleProposer
- Rename signature to GenerateImprovedToolModuleDescriptionsFromFeedback
- Make base signature generic (current_predictor_instruction)
- Dynamically add extract fields only for ReAct modules
- Use prefix checks (REACT_MODULE_PREFIX) for reliable type detection
- Support both 1-predictor (tool) and 2-predictor (ReAct) modules
- Update routing to handle both TOOL_MODULE_PREFIX and REACT_MODULE_PREFIX
- Clean variable names: primary_predictor_key, extract_predictor_key
- Update all docstrings to reflect tool-using modules (not just ReAct)

* refactor(gepa): eliminate create-delete pattern in base_program build

- Process ReAct modules first, then individual predictors
- Skip predictors already part of module configs (check inside JSON)
- Remove redundant base_program.pop() calls
- No duplicate enable_tool_optimization checks

* refactor(gepa): eliminate ReAct coupling in build_program

Replace ReAct-specific logic with generic approach:

Before:
- isinstance(ReAct) checks
- Direct access to module.react/module.extract/module.tools
- Separate if/elif branches for instruction updates

After:
- Program-level __dict__ traversal to find tools
- Unified aggregation: plain strings ‚Üí module config overrides
- Single application loop (no duplication)

Why __dict__ traversal:
Tools can be declared as single attributes (self.tool), lists
(self.tools=[...]), or dicts (self.tools={...}), and nested in
any dspy.Module. Traversing __dict__ finds all tools regardless
of how they're structured, without coupling to specific module types.

This makes the code resilient to ReAct internal changes and works
for any module using dspy.Tool.

* refactor(gepa): apply code cleanup principles consistently

- Use tuple syntax for startswith() (more Pythonic)
- Remove unnecessary try-except for JSON parsing (we control the source)

These follow the same principles applied in build_program refactor.

* refactor(gepa): unify config extraction patterns

- Use isinstance(v, str) for predictor filtering (type-based)
- Use .get("tools", {}) for tools extraction (more Pythonic)

Both changes make the code more consistent and resilient to
config structure changes.

* refactor(gepa): remove verbose logs and consolidate comments

Remove ~25 debug/info logs per maintainer feedback:
- Internal routing/processing logs
- Trace processing details
- Reflective example breakdowns
- Config building verbosity

Consolidate multi-line comments into concise single lines while
preserving important context (WHY, not WHAT).

Document that this is a workaround for ReAct's multiple predictor

Fail fast with clear error if DSPy's ReAct design changes (missing extract.predict).
Better than silently skipping broken modules.

author: Chen Qian

message:
Avoid unwanted exception chaining when running async tool in sync context (#9092)

Running async tool under sync context (require `settings.allow_tool_async_sync_conversion`) is handled by `Tool._run_async_in_sync`. If there's no running event loop, we used to run the coroutine directly when handling the `RuntimeError` raised by `asyncio.get_running_loop()`. This resulted in exception chaining, where the error raised by the tool will be chained with the `RuntimeError` raised by `asyncio`. Since the result will be passed to the LM as tool call result, such behavior is regarded as unnecessary leak of implementation detail, and will diverge the result of running with `async` and in sync. Move the real call outside of the `except` block will resolve the problem.

## Before

```
Execution error in retrieve: 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".venv\Lib\site-packages\dspy\adapters\types\tool.py", line 167, in _run_async_in_sync
    loop = asyncio.get_running_loop()
RuntimeError: no running event loop

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".venv\Lib\site-packages\dspy\predict\react.py", line 111, in forward
    trajectory[f"observation_{idx}"] = self.tools[pred.next_tool_name](**pred.next_tool_args)
                                       ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File ".venv\Lib\site-packages\dspy\utils\callback.py", line 326, in sync_wrapper
    return fn(instance, *args, **kwargs)
  File ".venv\Lib\site-packages\dspy\adapters\types\tool.py", line 176, in __call__
    result = self.func(**parsed_kwargs)
  File "src\retrieval\tool.py", line 169, in retrieve
    result = run_request(kwargs)
             ~~~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^^^
ValueError: Invalid request
```

## After

```
Execution error in retrieve: 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".venv\Lib\site-packages\dspy\predict\react.py", line 111, in forward
    trajectory[f"observation_{idx}"] = self.tools[pred.next_tool_name](**pred.next_tool_args)
                                       ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File ".venv\Lib\site-packages\dspy\utils\callback.py", line 326, in sync_wrapper
    return fn(instance, *args, **kwargs)
  File ".venv\Lib\site-packages\dspy\adapters\types\tool.py", line 176, in __call__
    result = self.func(**parsed_kwargs)
  File "src\retrieval\tool.py", line 169, in retrieve
    result = run_request(kwargs)
             ~~~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^^^
ValueError: Invalid request
```

message:
fix(dspy): exclude gpt-5-chat from reasoning model classification (#9033)

The regex pattern for identifying reasoning models was incorrectly
matching gpt-5-chat, causing it to be subject to reasoning model
validation requirements and attempting to pass reasoning parameters
that Azure's API doesn't support for this model.

Updated the regex to use negative lookahead (?!-chat) to exclude
gpt-5-chat while still allowing other gpt-5 variants like gpt-5-mini,
gpt-5-nano, and gpt-5-pro to be recognized as reasoning models.

- Updated regex pattern in dspy/clients/lm.py
- Added test case for gpt-5-chat in test_reasoning_model_token_parameter
- Added dedicated test test_gpt_5_chat_not_reasoning_model

Fixes issue where gpt-5-chat (Azure AI Foundry) was incorrectly
classified as a reasoning model, preventing normal usage with
standard temperature and max_tokens values.

message:
[Feature] GEPA: Add custom component selection logic support (#8765)

* Initial tests and changes to dspy.GEPA

* Cleanup tests

* Cleanup

* Cleanup

* Cleanup

* Update gepa to 0.0.9

* Small update to lock file

* Update to gepa==0.0.10

* Update to gepa==0.0.11

* Update tests and GEPA docstring

* Update to gepa==0.0.12

* Add test comparing round_robin vs all component selector behavior

Enhanced test coverage to verify that the 'all' component selector actually updates all components simultaneously, while 'round_robin' updates only one component per iteration.

The test directly compares the behavior of both selectors by examining the first candidate generated, confirming that 'all' updates both classifier and generator instructions while 'round_robin' updates only one.

* Add DictDummyLM based test for custom instruction proposer + custom component selector integration

Added `test_workflow_with_custom_instruction_proposer_and_component_selector()` that validates the integration of both custom instruction proposer and custom component selector working together using real LLM response data.

Features:
- TimeReader module with multiple components (hour_predictor, minute_predictor)
- MultiModalInstructionProposer for image-based instruction generation
- Custom component selector that selects all components simultaneously
- Real LLM conversation data via DictDummyLM pattern

* Update tests/teleprompt/test_gepa.py

message:
Add custom instruction_proposer support to GEPA with multimodal (dspy.Image) handling (#8737)

* Add custom instruction_proposer support to GEPA with multimodal handling

- Add instruction_proposer parameter to GEPA.__init__ for custom proposal logic
- Implement MultiModalProposer that handles dspy.Image and other custom types
- Preserve structured image data in reflection LM calls (no serialization)
- Add comprehensive test suite for multimodal instruction proposal
- Support both text-only and multimodal instruction generation workflows
- Fix GEPA compatibility issues with image-based DSPy modules

This enables GEPA optimization to work with visual content while maintaining
proper image handling throughout the reflection and instruction proposal process.

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

* Simlpify instruction_proposal

* Update instruction_proposer docstring

* Update instruction_proposal protocol to reuse the existing ProposalFn from gepa, enabling more holistic proposals

* Remove typing if

* Add propose_new_text comment back as documentation

* Simplify multimodal proposer creation

* Refactor GEPA instruction proposer to use class-based approach

  Replace the factory function `create_multimodal_proposer()` with
  `MultiModalInstructionProposer` class that directly implements GEPA's
  ProposalFn protocol. This follows DSPy's established coding patterns
  where major callable abstractions are implemented as classes with
  __call__ methods.

FUNCTION                   MEAN (ms)       MEDIAN (ms)
dict version (new)           124.5                  123.6
set version   (old)            165.5                  171.8

message:
fix(build): regenerate requirements.txt from pyproject.toml

Use uv to generate requirements.txt from pyproject.toml to include only
core dependencies. This removes optional provider dependencies (cohere,
anthropic, groq, etc.) and eliminates dependency conflicts. Users can
install provider support via extras: pip install -e ".[anthropic]"

message:
feat(bedrock): add image support to Bedrock

Adds comprehensive image support to the Bedrock provider by converting OpenAI-style image parts to Bedrock's native format.

- Add _normalize_bedrock_image_format() to map image types to Bedrock format
- Add _openai_image_part_to_bedrock() to convert OpenAI-style image parts
- Update _prepare_bedrock_converse_kwargs_internal() to handle image content conversion
- Add comprehensive test coverage for image format normalization and conversion

message:
fix: implement disable_pydantic_error_url via monkey-patching

The original implementation tried to set the PYDANTIC_ERRORS_INCLUDE_URL
environment variable after Pydantic had already imported. Since Pydantic
reads this variable at import time, the function had no effect.

This fix uses monkey-patching to replace ValidationError.__str__() with
a version that filters out URLs from error messages. This works correctly
regardless of when the function is called.

Fixes #1826

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>
author: Jason Liu

message:
fix: clear default_factory when making fields optional in Partial

When creating optional fields in Partial models, we now properly clear
the default_factory attribute in addition to setting a default value.
This prevents Pydantic 2.12.0+ validation errors that reject fields
with both default and default_factory set.

Fixes #1861

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

message: docs(validation): add context parameter examples and fix error output (#1833) # docs(validation): add context parameter examples and fix error output ## Summary Addresses two documentation issues reported by Mr-Ruben in Issues #1825 and #1826: 1. **Adds comprehensive `context` parameter documentation** to retrying.md and reask_validation.md with working examples showing: - How to pass `context=` parameter to `client.chat.completions.create()` - How to access context in validators using `ValidationInfo` - Citation verification using context-based validation - Context combined with Jinja templating 2. **Fixes Issue #1826**: Corrects misleading example output in reask_validation.md that showed Pydantic error URLs still appearing after calling `disable_pydantic_error_url()` ## Review & Testing Checklist for Human - [ ] **Test the code examples**: Copy and run the new context validation examples to verify they work with current Instructor API - [ ] **Verify ValidationInfo.context usage**: Confirm that `info.context.get('key')` is the correct way to access context in Pydantic validators - [ ] **Check disable_pydantic_error_url() behavior**: Test that this function actually removes URLs from error messages as claimed in the fixed examples - [ ] **API consistency**: Ensure the `context=` parameter usage matches current Instructor documentation and implementation ### Notes This addresses the documentation gaps identified in Mr-Ruben's issues where the v1 blog post promised `context` documentation in retrying/validation pages but it was missing. All examples follow the self-contained code block requirement with complete imports. Requested by Jason Liu (@jxnl) Link to Devin run: https://app.devin.ai/sessions/1ffc5d4493c540678ee84f27652fce9f ---- > [!IMPORTANT] > Enhances documentation with `context` parameter examples and corrects error output in validation docs. > > - **Documentation Enhancements**: > - Adds `context` parameter examples to `reask_validation.md` and `retrying.md`, demonstrating usage in dynamic validation and context-based validation with retries. > - Examples include passing `context` to `client.chat.completions.create()` and accessing it in validators via `ValidationInfo`. > - Demonstrates context usage with Jinja templating and citation verification. > - **Error Output Correction**: > - Fixes misleading example output in `reask_validation.md` by removing Pydantic error URLs after `disable_pydantic_error_url()` is called. > > This description was created by [](https://www.ellipsis.dev?ref=567-labs%2Finstructor&utm_source=github&utm_medium=referral) for d16770001d1886ea23b39fcf5a21169a8659526c. You can [customize](https://app.ellipsis.dev/567-labs/settings/summaries) this summary. It will automatically update as commits are pushed.

message: fix: Handle Gemini chunk.text ValueError when finish_reason=1 (#1809) Fixes issue #1808 where Gemini models hitting token limits cause ValueError when accessing chunk.text due to missing Part objects. Changes: - Add graceful error handling in extract_json() for GEMINI_JSON and GENAI_STRUCTURED_OUTPUTS modes - Skip chunks with invalid Parts instead of crashing - Preserve existing behavior for other ValueError types - Add comprehensive tests for both sync and async scenarios The fix allows streaming responses to continue processing valid chunks even when some chunks are incomplete due to token limits. Amp-Thread-ID: https://ampcode.com/threads/T-1bfe4270-cd9b-4c65-be2e-23a0f589dc10 ---- > [!IMPORTANT] > Fixes `ValueError` handling in `extract_json` functions for `GEMINI_JSON` and `GENAI_STRUCTURED_OUTPUTS` modes by skipping invalid chunks. > > - **Behavior**: > - In `partial.py`, `extract_json()` and `extract_json_async()` now handle `ValueError` for `GEMINI_JSON` and `GENAI_STRUCTURED_OUTPUTS` modes by skipping chunks with invalid `Part` objects. > - Preserves existing behavior for other `ValueError` types by re-raising them. > - **Tests**: > - New tests in `test_gemini_chunk_error.py` for both sync and async scenarios to verify handling of invalid `Part` objects in `GEMINI_JSON` and `GENAI_STRUCTURED_OUTPUTS` modes. > - Tests ensure valid chunks are processed and invalid ones are skipped, and that other `ValueError` types are re-raised. > > This description was created by [](https://www.ellipsis.dev?ref=567-labs%2Finstructor&utm_source=github&utm_medium=referral) for 11ed2eae12098106bc36380afb6b1637f957ed70.
